Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement: Testing for archaic hominid introgression in Eritrean and Yemeni modern human genomes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
There is strong consensus among scientists that modern humans evolved in Africa and then dispersed throughout Europe and Asia around 60 thousand years ago. Until recently, this process was thought to have occurred without any genetic input from Neanderthals or other archaic humans. In contrast, recent research in anthropological genetics has suggested there were minor levels of genetic interbreeding with Neanderthals and the newly described "Denisovans" from Denisova cave in Siberia. These arguments are based on comparisons of the draft Neanderthal genome to a number of human whole genomes sequences; however, none of the whole human genomes came from the Horn of Africa or southern Arabia, which are regions critical to studies of the first human dispersals out of Africa. It also has been questioned whether the evidence for Neanderthal interbreeding could instead be an artifact of the ancestral human population not randomly breeding (i.e., reflective of genetic structure in the ancient African population).

Using whole genome sequences from Eritrea and Yemen, doctoral student Deven Vyas (University of Florida), under the guidance of Dr. Connie Mulligan, will test the contrasting hypotheses of genetic interbreeding with archaic humans versus ancient population structure in Africa. The latest next-generation sequencing technologies will be utilized to generate whole human genome sequences, and newly developed analytical methods will statistically test support for the two competing hypotheses. The data have significant implications for our understanding of the evolutionary history of humans and our knowledge of the populations and processes that contributed to the modern human gene pool. These novel genetic data from Eritrean and Yemeni individuals will be publicly available to researchers all over the world, facilitating future research. In addition, undergraduate students interested in scientific research will be assisting in this project, continuing the strong tradition of mentoring and training undergraduates to conduct scientific research in the Department of Anthropology's Human Genetics Laboratory at the University of Florida, directed by Dr. Mulligan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For this project, we investigated the dispersal of early modern humans out of Africa and Neanderthal introgression events. These two events are closely related as introgression is understood to have occurred very soon after leaving Africa. Early modern humans are thought to have either followed the Northern Dispersal Route (NDR) and crossed from Northeast Africa into the Levant or followed the Southern Dispersal Route (SDR) across the Bab el-Mandeb from the Horn of Africa into southern Arabia. We were interested in testing support for the NDR and SDR and analyzing and comparing Neanderthal introgression at the ground-zeroes of both routes, namely the Levant and southern Arabia.

As part of this project, we conducted three studies. For the first study, we conducted Bayesian phylogenetic analyses on 113 Yemeni mitochondrial genomes alongside 338 published mitochondrial genomes to test if modern Yemeni mitochondrial diversity is the product of more recent or more ancient migrations. We found that Yemeni mitochondrial variation is the product of many recent Holocene migrations from a variety regions including the Levant, the Caucasus, and sub-Saharan Africa (Vyas et al. 2016, Am J Phys Anthropol, 159:383-393).

For our second study, we genotyped 90 Yemeni individuals for >600,000 SNPs (single nucleotide polymorphisms), which we analyzed alongside published data from Levantine and other southern Arabian populations and other comparative populations. To test support for the NDR and SDR, we compared how closely related the Levantine and southern Arabian populations are to African populations living near the starting points of both routes and to 124 other non-African populations from around the world. Our expectation was the populations living along the used route would have be less closely related to other non-Africans. Our results indicate that both the Levantine and southern Arabians have similar relationships to all the compared populations, which suggests both routes remain viable. We concluded that this genetic similarity may be due to a longer than expected history of gene flow between the Levant and southern Arabia.

For our third study, we continued to analyze SNP data to compare Neanderthal introgression between the Levant and southern Arabia. We found that both regions have statistically indistinguishable amounts of introgression from each other. We identified and analyzed Neanderthal SNPs within our dataset to compare how introgression is spread across the genome in both regions. We discovered that Neanderthal SNPs have extremely similar frequencies in the Levant and southern Arabia. As introgression is so similar in these regions (based on both amount and Neanderthal SNP frequencies), we posit that contemporary Levantine and southern Arabian populations likely descended from the same ancestral, introgressed population (as opposed to introgression spreading from region to another by gene flow). We also infer that for these Neanderthals SNPs to maintain very similar frequencies in both regions, ongoing gene flow would be necessary, consistent with our conclusions from the second study.

For this project, we generated novel SNP genotyping data from Yemeni samples, which will be publicly accessible upon publication of our results. Yemeni and other southern Arabian populations are generally under-represented (or absent) in many studies of human genomic diversity. We feel our data will help to solve this problem. Furthermore, we believe our project ties in well with the general public’s great interest in human evolution. With the arrival of the Neanderthal and Denisovan genomes and the concept of interbreeding between modern humans and archaic humans, interest in human evolution has been especially high.
